key_points: The Senate voted to acquit former President Donald Trump in his second impeachment trial, with a 43 not guilty to 57 guilty vote.
Democrats briefly considered calling witnesses after new details emerged about Trump's behavior on January 6, but ultimately decided against it.
The trial highlighted the strong hold Trump still has over the Republican Party.
Trump's absence from Twitter has made him a much quieter political force.
Republican women, including Rep. Liz Cheney and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, showed courage by standing up to Trump.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell criticized Trump but voted to acquit, citing the argument that the trial was unconstitutional for a former president.
Trump's acquittal leaves open the possibility of him holding future office.
The impeachment managers used extensive video footage to make their case against Trump.
There are ongoing criminal investigations and pending cases related to the Capitol riot and Trump's efforts to influence election results.
Trump's influence and the events leading to the Capitol riot will continue to be subjects of public and legal scrutiny.
